text: <@U02BA5QPQ04> has joined the channel
Not sure if this is a stupid question, but if you took the IP mid odds at lets say 1f out across all races, how accurate are they on average at the percentage chance of winning?

elements.text: Not sure if this is a stupid question, but if you took the IP mid odds at lets say 1f out across all races, how accurate are they on average at the percentage chance of winning?

text:
I think it depends on the sophistication of your analysis. It makes more sense to look at matched prices than a mid price, if you take all bets that match at (say) 2 then 1/2 of them do win, you can go across all price increments that way and you'll find the results surprisingly consistent so superficially it appears quite efficient.

That said, you can also find plenty of value opportunities and it's entirely obvious even just from looking at the charts that the markets are often irrational, although I'm no sure how you show that with a statistical test.

You can reconcile the markets' apparent efficiency with its known inefficiency by recognising that there are equal opportunities on both sides of the book, in other words the value taken by backers is equal to that taken by layers.

elements.text:
I think it depends on the sophistication of your analysis. It makes more sense to look at matched prices than a mid price, if you take all bets that match at (say) 2 then 1/2 of them do win, you can go across all price increments that way and you'll find the results surprisingly consistent so superficially it appears quite efficient.

That said, you can also find plenty of value opportunities and it's entirely obvious even just from looking at the charts that the markets are often irrational, although I'm no sure how you show that with a statistical test.

You can reconcile the markets' apparent efficiency with its known inefficiency by recognising that there are equal opportunities on both sides of the book, in other words the value taken by backers is equal to that taken by layers.

text: ...and totally not a stupid question by the way.

elements.text: ...and totally not a stupid question by the way.

text: matched prices makes more sense to me also, something I need to look into deeper but certainly interesting that you say across a large sample (lets say all uk races for 20 years) the matched prices would line up with the implied probability, although still loads of opportunity like pre-off markets.  An average hides alot.

text: Question: How many of you bet/trade all AU + US + GB/IRE races and doing well at all of them?  I don't have problem being profitable at GB/IRE races but for months I have not been able to crack AU markets and all the $$$ I made from former I lost them trying to crack the latter. I also get mixed results for the US markets, but that's probably due to both the markets liquidity and volatility.

elements.text: Question: How many of you bet/trade all AU + US + GB/IRE races and doing well at all of them?  I don't have problem being profitable at GB/IRE races but for months I have not been able to crack AU markets and all the $$$ I made from former I lost them trying to crack the latter. I also get mixed results for the US markets, but that's probably due to both the markets liquidity and volatility.

text: Cracked aus racing from the getgo. Took me almost 10 years to figure out uk/ire racing :flushed: - for me different strategy than aus racing. Cracked aus and uk dogs about 5 years ago. Used to do US racing but the market moved on the edge that I had.
